user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdEqual(osal_id_t object_id1, osal_id_t object_id2)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id1) == OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id2));
}
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdIsValid(osal_id_t object_id)
{
    osal_objtype_t objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);
    return (objtype > OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && objtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
explanation: The other symbols in the provided code do not involve pointers that could reasonably be const-qualified: token and obj parameters are already declared const; OS_ObjectIdEqual and OS_ObjectIdIsValid operate on value types (osal_id_t/osal_objtype_t), not pointer types; macro definitions are not pointer declarations. Therefore they do not need investigation for Rule 8.13.
